title: 107_hr4155
content: The Act titled "District of Columbia Legislative Autonomy Act of 2002" eliminates congressional review of newly-passed District laws. The District of Columbia Home Rule Act is amended to remove congressional review of newly-passed District laws. Section 602 and 604 are struck, and the exercise of rulemaking power by Congress is specified. The House of Representatives and the Senate have the power to make rules, which will be considered part of each House's rules and can override other rules if inconsistent. Each House has the constitutional right to change these rules as they see fit. SEC. 3. CONFORMING AMENDMENTS. The District of Columbia Home Rule Act is amended in various sections, including changes to subsections and the removal of certain provisions. Payments by the District for principal, interest, or other obligations are not subject to appropriation. The District of Columbia Home Rule Act is amended to remove subsections and provisions related to payments not subject to appropriation for revenue anticipation notes. The District of Columbia Home Rule Act is amended to remove subsections and provisions related to payments for revenue anticipation notes. Amendments include changes to sections regarding initiative and referendum procedures. The District of Columbia Home Rule Act is amended to remove subsections and provisions related to payments for revenue anticipation notes, as well as changes to sections regarding initiative and referendum procedures. The District of Columbia Home Rule Act is amended by removing certain subsections and provisions related to payments for revenue anticipation notes, as well as changes to sections regarding initiative and referendum procedures. Additionally, amendments are made to specific sentences within the Act. The amendments made by this Act, effective October 1, 2002, apply to acts of the District of Columbia passed by the Council and signed by the Mayor, vetoed by the Mayor and repassed by the Council, passed by the Council and allowed to become effective by the Mayor without signature, or ratified by a majority of registered qualified electors voting on the initiative or referendum.
